review:
After 3 playthroughs, I decided it's time to give this game a review. a different one from the majority of "Not Recommended" you see here. Mafia III Is deeply flawed and after the Definitive Edition upgrade, it yet remains the same but it had something special that kept me playing it for such a long time, I simply couldn't leave a thumb down on it.

[h1]Story[/h1]
üîπMafia III tells the tale of Lincoln Clay, a colored man who got screwed by the greed of the Italian mob ruling the fictional New Bordeaux based on New Orleans. He loses his family and father figure and now he's out for revenge. However, this is not your average vengeance story that ends just with killing the bad guy. Lincoln wants to take everything Sal Marcano the mob boss has worked for, makes him suffer just the way he did by busting up his rackets, taking over the city district by district and killing closest to Sal including his wife, son, and brothers. Throughout the game, after each main mission completed comes up a cutscene where the people who knew Lincoln the most are participating in a documentary show on his life and actions, picturing real-life photos and videos. This is where is the story shines the most as you realize piece by piece on Lincoln's background and the damage he inflicted on the mob.
üîπHangar 13 made the right call giving you a handful of choices for how to end Lincoln's fate which added to the replay value.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b][u]Showing them who's in charge[/u][/b]
üîπProbably the only aspect of Mafia III that covered for the whole game. Taking over the city after progressing enough through the story to unlock all 3 underbosses can be tedious. The same style of "Damage this business enough to draw out the capo" or "Make the informant talk so he gives up where to damage the business enough to draw out the capo" will bore you to death but at the same time, it has a special and strong pull making you go after every point of interest deliberately (This might have to do with the need for money as in for the base game it's your only big source of income). Then it's time to confront the lieutenants in the main story missions which play out differently and take place under different circumstances that'll kick up the game considerably.

[b][u]Driving[/u][/b]
üîπCouldn't be done any better imho. Great variety of vehicles with a dozen 60s muscle cars which all are wonderful to drive around. Unlike other open-world TPS games where cars are made out of tin can and smallest bump in the road makes your car goes flying, Mafia III vehicles actually weigh for something. Crashing into the environment and other cars won't go so lightly. your car might not spin out of control but certainly takes a huge hit to the speed. On the other hand, driving mechanics are masterfully done close to a point you'd think they're taken out of an arcade racing game. Grip, Acceleration, Handling, and just everything about it is solid. Not to mention there comes a good variety of customizations for cars unlocked by doing races around the city.

[b][u]Gunplay[/u][/b]
üîπI've been using Max Payne 3 as a measuring system for how cool the shootings play in a game and Mafia III is almost nothing less than that (Hell, it even comes with a slow-mo ability just like Max Payne). Although some of the weapons might not have proper sound effects but shooting them regardless, feels like packing a real punch, enemies react to being shot, and the recoil kicks back just enough to delivers a satisfying experience. The Covering system is also implemented perfectly. Sticky covers where you can easily get out by going in the opposite direction with the addition of blind shooting to create amazing and realistic gunfights.

[b][u]The dumbed-down AI[/u][/b]
üîπYou can choose to go in quiet or guns blazing shooting the place up, but AI remains the same dumb AI no matter what. Enemies have a few scripted behaviors such as "Searching, Aggressive, Combat". Nonetheless, you wouldn't notice a big difference between them. They would easily give up on searching for you, or situation can quickly escalate from aggressive to combat when you're warned for trespassing even if you're walking away, sometimes they storm your cover one by one so you'll have an easier time picking them off. Can't even stress enough on how AI provides a lackluster challenge during car pursuits by tending to only shoot out the tires and if they manage to stop your car, you can sit right there pissing yourself laughing and counting how many shots these cops gonna miss while standing right in front of your windshield.

[h1]Music and Sound[/h1]
üîπan OST of curated songs from Country, Blues, Soul to Classic Rock helping establish the southern mood of the 60s in the game. CCR's "Proud Mary", "Fortunate Son", "Born on the Bayou", Aretha Franklin's "Respect", "Somebody to Love" by Jefferson Airplane and many more impressive hits that simply won't fit the size of my review can be heard not only in your car but in every bar and diner around the city.
üîπConsidering the racist theme game was set on, the voice acting crew did a decent job with the southern accent and the black language. Alex Hernandez, Gordon Greene, Jay Acovone, and many others made their respective characters unforgettable for me.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
üîπThis is the spark that burned Mafia III down. I could simply say technical issues and put a plus infinite sign in front of it but I'll go into some of them anyway. Not gonna complain much on the optimization because miraculously I managed to finish the game twice on a GT730 1GB and 3rd time on a GTX1050 that got me around 30fps on max settings with only a couple of crashes during the entire playthrough and time to time 2-3sec freezes which weren't something I couldn't put up with.
[list]
    [*]Reflection effects don't work properly most of the time with cars' surface and upon going indoors, Lincoln and objects suddenly render with a desaturated (Like silvery metal) texture for several seconds until the actual thing kicks in
    [*]Overall Image is a BLURRY SHET-SHOW to an eyesight weakening level (Use of ReShade along with Image sharpening feature is highly recommended)
    [*]Intrusive HUD with no option to limit or turn off that ruins the immersion
    [*]View Distance not befitting an 8th gen AAA title especially for the PC port
    [*]Clothing during cutscenes stretch all over when characters start moving
    [*]Lincoln can have a bottomless shadow during daylight.
    [*]Poor and somewhat unclear Graphics settings
    [*]Skybox seems low quality
[/list]
[b]And the list goes on but with every low comes a high[/b]
[list]
    [*]Attention to details around the world whether outdoors or indoors are extraordinary and makes up for any other failures
    [*]At least cutscenes are sharp and crispy (Pre-rendered and In-game), letting you enjoy the narrative
    [*]Motion Captures and Facial expressions are to a degree jaw-dropping
    [*]The city looks alive and vivid during both day and night
    [*]Lincoln's movement animations are super smooth
[/list]

[h1]DLC Contents[/h1]
üîπAll 3 DLCs come with a short but rather interesting storyline (Adding a new island and Sinclair Parish which both are amazingly more beautiful than New Bordeaux) and extend the gameplay further by adding side quests and introducing interesting businesses to work on such as renovating Sammy's bar that might set you back for thousands of dollars but wouldn't compare to the satisfaction you get from building and running your bar. Now to make up for the loss on the bar, you can get your own freaking GROW HOUSE running. Acquiring new strains, mixing them with new seeds, giving sick names to your new custom plants, watch them grow, and sell them on the market for a fat cash-flow.


[b]Here I go hitting 8000 character limit :P[/b]
In the end, I'm a person who finagles too much with a game until I can enjoy it, others might not have the patience but Mafia III deserves your second chance.

review:
First of all, this game won't be for everyone.  It's not perfect.  As a game it sometimes struggles with repetitive gameplay loops, and it has some technical issues.

But I love it dearly.  Let me tell you why.

First of all, the story.  This is the best mix of motion capture, voice acting, and writing I have ever seen in a game.  There is a tremendous amount of scripted story in this game, and it is really, really well done.  The team behind this team have done a great job capturing all the elements that make compelling drama and making them work within the limits of in-game cutscenes.

Second, the setting.  1960's New Orleans (er, New Bordeaux) is very well realised.   It's both large, and feels like a cohesive place.  The music works really well, and it avoids the problems that recent open world games have had where every location feels like a copy-paste of the last.  The setting also works nicely with the plot, allowing (very prescient) themes of racism to edge their way in - which helps make Lincoln a much more sympathetic character.  (After all, if the whole system is against you then what's so wrong about knocking it down?)

That said, the game has it's problems.  For me, they aren't gamebreakers - but for some they will be.

First, the game's tech.  Crank everything up to full detail and it will look like a smeared mess.  Pop in is  aggressive and texture pop in occasionally goes haywire on random objects.  Every now and then the game will bug, and I found myself having to load to the last checkpoint.  Textures are also a distracting mix of the very good and godawful.

(My advice: Turn Anti aliasing down and turn off motion blur.  Strong Temporal AA and the aggressive Blur functions make everything blurry and fuzzy for me).

Second, the gameplay.  The difficulty curve is weirdly difficult during the first few 'tutorial' missions, which can be off putting once you start playing.  When you realise you need to treat it more like a stealth game than a third person shooter it will click into place.  It's also occasionally repetitive - and throws a number of onerous fetch quests at you.  The setting is nice, but being forced to endlessly drive slow vehicles across it sucks the joy right out of the setting.

So there you have it.  If you are willing to put up with gameplay I would characterise as 'passable' overall, in exchange for an amazing setting and well told story, then I would recommend the game to you.

review:
[h1] My Name's Lincoln Clay [/h1]
Lincoln Clay ‚Äì a Vietnam War veteran who returns home in 1968 to his old neighbourhood in New Bordeaux (~ New Orleans) ‚Äì is the protagonist of Mafia III, the third game in the Mafia Series. Mother Dominican, and father white, possibly Italian, as Father James says when talking about Lincoln: [i] ‚ÄúNot that it mattered - back then if you looked black, you were black. Same as today, I suppose.‚Äù [/i] 

[b] To make it short: [/b] it's a good third-person open world action-adventure game with a great story ‚Äì characters and cinematic cutscenes ‚Äì good gunplay and a fantastic soundtrack. It's got a few evident defects (first of all a few persistent bugs and repetitive racket-related missions), but classifying this game as rubbish, as I've seen happening many times, is as ignorant as superficial. Certainly, it's a very underrated game.

I‚Äôve played the Definitive Edition, so I've never had to deal with its problematic debut in 2016. And judging it now, [b] it's everything except unplayable. [/b] Before blaming the game, I'd check if you can handle it. A ROG notebook with a GTX 1060 can run GTA V, RDR 2 and Mafia III in high settings in 1080p without problems. And be careful the Nvidia control panel didn't choose to run it with the integrated graphic card. If so, simply switch to the dedicated GPU.

Graphically [b] it's a nice-looking game. [/b] Hangar 13's proprietary engine, here at its debut, would have needed a few improvements and a little more optimization, but combined with a fine reconstruction of New Bordeaux can give quite realistic imagery and great visuals. There're still some technical issues such as a limited depth of field, texture pop-in, especially while driving, and issues with some reflections (who said mirrors?). Talking about bugs and glitches, despite I've played the story twice, I've never encountered anything so annoying, except some situation where NPCs get stuck (fixed reloading the last checkpoint) and unfortunately several glitched achievements.

[b] Storytelling and characters are simply great. [/b] It‚Äôs a tale of revenge, in a period (and in a country) full of violence, racism and mass protest movements. Lincoln is a cool character, and John Donovan is simply amazing. I'd bet many players have never accepted the fact of playing with such a character, because prejudice and bigotry are all over the place. Anyway. Nice vehicle models and pretty good driving (the simulated one). [b] Loved the gunplay, really satisfying. [/b] The weapons feel heavy, you can feel the impacts of the gunshots. Good cover system and animations in general. Game's big fault, as I said, is the constant reiteration of the same gameplay mechanic for the racket-related missions. But the missions against the Marcano Crime Family are really cool, as well as the locations, from the abandoned amusement park to The Royal Hotel and the Casino.

And what's better than driving around New Orleans, downtown and surroundings, in a ‚Äò68 Chevrolet or a Ford Mustang while listening House of the Rising Sun, Born To Be Wild or Sympathy For The Devil on the radio‚Ä¶

review:
While the game can be quite repetitive, and the fact that you have to do some of these repetitive steps to progress, otherwise the scripted missions are good, the gameplay, characters, music choice and story are also really good.
The fact that the game gives you the option to play aggressively or discreetly is nice, since I like infiltration a lot, I mostly played like this, trying to go undiscovered as much as possible with silent takedowns, moving bodies out of the path of the ennemies, and so on.
The DLC missions were also really good to play, and gave a nice break during the repetitive steps of the main story.
People seem to complain a lot about bugs and such, I've personally only encountered one bug, which was an infinite loading screen after completing a side quest, a quick reload and everything was back to normal, and my progress was saved.
So, to end this, I definitely recommend this game

The fact that the game gives you the option to play aggressively or discreetly is nice, since I like infiltration a lot, I mostly played like this, trying to go undiscovered as much as possible with silent takedowns, moving bodies out of the path of the ennemies, and so on.
The DLC missions were also really good to play, and gave a nice break during the repetitive steps of the main story.
People seem to complain a lot about bugs and such, I've personally only encountered one bug, which was an infinite loading screen after completing a side quest, a quick reload and everything was back to normal, and my progress was saved.

review:
Marfia 2 was a masterpiece. This is just.... not good

At first it looked promising, but interest is lost real quick.
If you enjoy doing the same thing over and over again, go here>kill these enemies with great ease> kill the leader>  see some more of the map> repeat. all while following a predictable storyline than this is for you. 
Its essentially a really bad Assassins Creed Game not a Mafia game.

review:
One of the biggest technical mess and waste of potential I've ever played.
The story and characters are great, and that's it, everything else is bad.
It's riddled with bugs and glitches, doesn't run well, the keyboard/mouse support is pure trash, and to top it all, the gameplay loop is basically " Pointless Side Missions: The Game".

review:
I was excited as ever when I got gifted this game yesterday (25th June 2020), I remember playing it when it originally released, at a friends house, and was just disappointed at how bad the game was in looks and performance (I had played Mafia 2 on PS3, a cousin had lent it to me, and then again on PC after buying it, the only game I have ever played TWICE through, and loved every second of it), and hearing it was getting a definitive edition gave me hope that maybe the developers had put some extra time into actually making this something they could be proud of, but no.

This game runs like absolute dog Sh*t. 

To call it a "definitive edition" is an insult to actual definitive editions that improve on the original game.

The game looks worse, and runs worse than when it did before it got the "definitive edition" title. 

Nothing has changed. If anything, lighting is worse. Graphics looks worse than Mafia 2 (The original one) and it runs like absolute crap, like, there are cutscenes running at 20 FPS! A CUTSCENE!

Honestly, it's basically a money grab for the devs, a Scam if you must, to release this as a "definitive edition" is a lie. 

This dev studio honestly disgusts me more than EA.

I was given this as a gift by a dear friend, and the fact I'm bothering to write a review given how I didn't spend a cent on this game, hopefully, is a eye opener to some of you.

I'm currently streaming it if you really wanna see how bad it is, but that's up to you.

Absolutely disappointing.

review:
Underated game.
If you like GTA or Saint's Row and want something different give it a shot.
The cut scenes and musical score is top notch. The writing is also pretty good.
Unfortunately, the game play has some let downs and there are limits in the game loop. There is also a few bugs and control issues. Get past that and it's a good time.

review:
I was excited to have a modern Mafia game and I wouldn't go so far to say this is a bad game... but I'd question whether or not you should buy this.
Audio issues, game locks and vehicle spawn bugs are annoying but are the least of the problems. The story is alright, but the gameplay through it relies on a repetitive un-rewarding gameplay cycle that isn't fun. 
I didn't like that Mafia 2 went to the effort to develop a large open world, but never gave a reason to explore or do anything in it. Mafia 3 fixes this with the open world, but most of the tasks are very mundane and you'll spend most your time driving from one end of the city to another, often forced to do so in a slow truck, and you need to pray no one shoots out a tire and triples the time it takes to make the trip.
This goes into direct contrast with the Associate system which is buttery smooth and delivers a bank, free high end cars of your choice and an arms dealer, to your location, for free, wherever you are in less than 10 seconds. It's tremendous how enjoyable this is.... but then the game expects you to drive 10 minutes across the city to start a mission where you drive all the way back again to shoot one guy. Repeat. Repeat. Repeat.
Atleast this game looks great, and with the classic music selection on point, I never felt out of place here. I just felt like my time was wasted on the mundane. If this was a more condense. linear game I might have less problems with the tedious, but then would have more complaints about the lack of open world utilisation.
If only Hanger 13 could find some other similar genre games and figure out how they manage player progression, mission rewards, open-world to improve upon.

Mafia 1 is one of my all time favs and playing this before it's remaster has me filled with hope... but I'm not having to calm, because this took the excitement away for me.

review:
I'm genuinely surprised by so many negative reviews. For me personally the game has three major flaws; the repetitive gameplay loop, the fact the civilian AI doesn't seem to mind you sneaking around their office block with a shotgun.. Lastly the story is great and I love the way it's told, it's just a shame it's so spread out. 

The story is awesome, the music is awesome, the moment to moment gameplay is genuinely great. The setting has made me want to visit New Orleans. If one enjoys media such as Goodfellas, Sopranos etc then like me you'll likely very much enjoy the scenes at the various locations. - The overweight "guido" in a vest sat outside a construction site playing cards with his pals. It all feels rather authentic. 

All in all I had a great time, however I broke up the gameplay by only playing in short sessions. I imagine if one was to do long 4 hour + sessions then the gameplay loop would get repetitive to the point of frustration. In small sizes (a district a day) and you'll get a good 2 weeks worth of awesome gameplay and will be left feeling satisfied.

Definitive Edition TL;DR: 82/100

Neutral:
- Revenge story heard 100 times before
- Fast driver sees people's tendency to jump under wheels of his car
- Graphical glitches in cut-scenes (Definitive Edition launch) solved by latest patch, now only very rare graphical glitches in the game world

Negative:
- Some bugs preventing further progress (solved by reloading checkpoint if possible or restarting game if frozen in loading)
- Repetitive missions
- Too many 'electronic parts' collectibles (over 350), good thing there's likely no achievement for getting all so only get as much as you need for unlocking 'towers'
- Post-DLC content feels like padding (again repetition)

Positive:
- Great characters
- Overall good story
- Interesting documentary approach to story-telling
- DLC stories are fun
- Action while repetitive tactics, engaging until the finale (and heard it will be again in original Mafia remake)
- Graphics (nothing added in Definitive Edition, still solid and nice-looking)

For DLC, I'd recommend to finish Faster, Baby! rather sooner than later because post-DLC content is driven by time passing.

Really enjoyed this game after I replayed kind of messed up Mafia 2 Remastered Edition (played original when it released) and finally got to Mafia 3 which I did postponed before. While the grind was strong (especially when I wanted to collect everything including the electronic parts) and some missions were repetitive, the story pieces when protagonist Lincoln finally got turn for action and main events, more than balanced it. This game will be left in my heart just next to Mafia and Mafia 2. Franchise didn't disappoint me. 82/100

review:
The gunplay and the story are awesome!

But (and that's a big BUT) it's bugged as hell! Especially at the car race ... first of all, your opponents honk all the time if they are directly behind you and they are behind you all the time because they speed forward if they fall behind. The other cars dodge unrealistically and people jump like lemmings on the street and when you run over them it often happens that your car makes an air jump.

AND ... why is the feature gone that makes cops stop you and collect a ticket if, for example, you drive too fast, ramming another car or racing over red? Why can't you drink anything in bars, eat anything in restaurants and refuel at gas stations?

especially when you play such a robin-hood-guy, you should not be tempted to rage badly and shoot everything that is in your way. You should go to a gas station / restaurant for other reasons  than robbing it!

I love mafia I because of the great driving feeling and that you can't ignore red traffic lights or hit other cars or even exceed the speed limit without watching at cops because they'll try to stop you if you do so.

This game does NOT feel like a Mafia-Game... it's unfortunately more like a GTA-Game!

review:
The number one complaint that most people have about this game is that the gameplay is repetitive. Which is true but it took me a while to really get sick of it, in fact I was almost finished the game but finally gave up because of the repetitive missions. The reason I kept playing for so long is because this game is also awesome in many ways. While the DLC also adds some much needed variation to the gameplay.

When you play through the game though you can see that the repetition is more of an unfortunate consequence of a better game play idea which makes up the bigger picture of what you are actually doing. Basically the idea is that you are taking over districts in the city and building your empire while assigning power to your under bosses. Which is fun in terms of the bigger picture but very repetitive and drawn out on a mission to mission basis. It‚Äôs actually just lazy game design because with a few tweaks and a bit more thought put into it they could have easily made an excellent game. There are some other disappointing design elements here too which break immersion such as not being able to close doors behind you. Considering the awesome level of detail in other areas these little oversights are disappointing.

I mean in general with this game there are great ideas and fun game play mixed with lazy design and blatant filler. There are also some out right stupid things that happen towards the end of the game that show a straight up lack of motivation by the developers. It‚Äôs a real shame because there are a lot of good things to say about this game too. If you buy it on a sale and reduce your expectations before playing you will most likely have a good time over all. 
 
Just like Mafia 2 this game has a genuinely awesome soundtrack which given that it‚Äôs based in the 1960‚Äôs is really enjoyable. As the main character is also black during a very racist time and place this game is interesting in the way that it deals with racism. It might actually be worth playing just to experience that aspect of it. It reminded me of Tarantino‚Äôs Django Unchained in the way it uses Racism as part of the main character's motivation. The developers also didn‚Äôt hold back when dealing with this topic and it‚Äôs a pretty unique game in that sense. 

There's some good level design here too with multiple entry points when approaching missions. The game looks gorgeous for the most part and there is some real attention to detail put into some of the environments. The cars are awesome and really fun to drive while the gun play is satisfying and well designed. There are also NPC services available such as a mobile gun shop which is nice. However the AI is screwed up so when they arrive they will usually crash straight into you or your vehicle. Uncle Joey Diaz from The Joe Rogan Experience podcast is in this game too with a short cameo appearance which is fun.

As a AAA game at full price Mafia 3 definitely deserves all the criticism that it has gotten since it‚Äôs release. It‚Äôs a real shame though because even though it‚Äôs seriously flawed there was also a lot of good work put into making this game. It‚Äôs definitely worth playing and I had fun with it, in fact it‚Äôs the perfect game for a Steam sale on PC. Hopefully Mafia 4 will follow through on the good things that this game does and deliver a more polished experience.

review: The first Mafia game was one of my favorites as kid. And while Mafia 2 wasn't groundbreaking storytelling, I loved that the first time around as well; enough to finally try the third game after being warned not to. I hoped that given some extra time, the game might actually be playable now. I was wrong. This collection (minus the first one, the main I wanted to play, because it isn't out) is just disappointing from top to bottom. It feels like fans of the franchise were exploited by an obvious cash grab, which I could genuinely look past if any of it was FUN. The remaster of II is perhaps (somehow) buggier than the original and I didn't play III before but it's just a terribly clunky and boring game as it stands now.

review:
Pros:
+ Atmosphere is incredible, can be very beautiful sometimes.
+ Amazing soundtrack
+ The graphics are decent
+ Very authentic New Orleans Environment
+ Driving can actually be quite fun, steering and maneuvering is quite satisfying.
+ Interesting lieutenant mechanics, being able to call in favours from others and try to keep everyone happy with owning a piece of the city each is a challenge.

Cons:
- All missions (but the prologue) are the same. Rush or sneak in, kill everyone, steal something/interrogate someone/destroy something.
- The weapons all feel kind of weak. A 44. Magnum should feel like a hand-cannon, not an Airsoft gun.
- Most of the cutscenes are not real cutscenes, so no cinematic effects and just two characters moving their badly animated lips.
- Buggy, low framerate from time to time, repeated crashes.
- Story is stretched out and predictable

review:
It¬¥s been a while since I wrote a review but I need to...

I will not talk about the game itself (which I hear it doesn¬¥t even come close to the other 2 entries), because I never played Mafia III.

So what is this review about?...
Well simple 30 minutes in and all I get from the launcher is "Your system doesn¬¥t meet minimum requirements", which is right I pass minimum eaily and even recommended.

While this message does appear in other games which I play with no issues, this one does not want me to play it.

In the 30 minutes I did nothing but "play" with the setting to at best get a camera control that rolls all around the character at outrageous speeds and a nice 23 to 68 frames per second that changes every single sentence the characters talked.

I will leave this review as is, until hopefully Hanger 13 fixes this game before launching the Mafia 1 Remastered (Mafia II worked well for me BTW)

review: Beautiful cars, GREAT music, top-notch acting, impressive facial emotions, and I LOVED the fact that you are able to determine the course of the story and wind up with a unique ending, depending on your choices leading up to the final confrontation.  There were some things I thought could've been done better, and definitely some disappointments.  Actually, for me, this game didn't feel at all like a "mafia" game, as much as the first two games did, mainly because of the protagonist's motivation for vengeance was front and center of it all.  If anything, Lincoln felt mostly indifferent to the factions at play, like they were secondary or even tertiary to his story.  I don't consider Mafia 3 as a "mafia" game, but for what it is overall, this game does stand on its own very well.

review:
A decent open world game with mediocre gameplay, mediocre narrative and a thick atmosphere.
Lots of content and replay value, but if you require a deep "Mafia" game and story, seek elsewhere.
The game is full of "go fetch" missions, but due to how they're designed, they do still offer some variation.

It's pretty cheap these days, and the most recent patches seem to have finally improved some of the glaring technical issues.

review:
I tried multiple times to get back into this game. Every time i come back to the game I'm always thinking to myself "Wonder why I never beat Mafia III, I'ma go play it." Then I download it and see why. Well this game has some of the worst graphics I've seen for a game released above the year 2015, the combat is so boring, yea the death animations are cool for anyone you kill but, it just becomes repetitive probably because you do literally the same 5 missions repeated throughout the whole game and one side mission where you steal a semi truck has been broken from release date and its still NOT FIXED. There's no fast travel so your stuck driving around with some of the most boring driving mechanics looking around at the shitty looking city and you do a LOT of driving in this game. If they added a fast travel in this game it would change a LOT of things but, they didn't which makes no sense. Maybe with a fast travel I could slug my way through this game. Spend your money else where, I don't mind repeating the same missions and clearing stuff out, hell I beat all the Far Cry's above 3, even got hundred percents on all of them probably because you could be creative and do different shit to kill your enemies. Here its boring and generic. 



I Rate 4/10

Cons: Easy things to do are complain, the ****** up the textures with there new update, lower fps due to update, basicly fetch quests to increase earn, repeative.
Hey but its got a rockin story.

review:
[h1][u]Game[/u][/h1]
[strike][b]Mafia III[/b][/strike] / [b][u]Social Justice Warrior III[/u][/b]

[h1][u]Story[/u][/h1]
About [strike][b]Mafia[/b][/strike] / [b][u]The Democratic Party and their militia army Ku Lux Klan.[/u][/b]
Italian Mafia is mentioned few time ingame to justify the name of the game.
They put some propaganda into the game that JFK was shot by Mafia, when everybody knows it was the CIA and the Dems.
Every spoken word in this game is verbal diarrhea, it was unbearable listening to this crap. Seriously i had to turn off the audio during some conversations.

[h1][u]Gameplay[/u][/h1]
Gamplay is good and i had fun with the game.

[b]God Wins[/b]

review:
Should you Play mafia in 2020?  That depends on the person you ask.
 
The good:
The story is by far the shining star in the game, playing out as if it's a documentary. The cut scenes when they decide to actually load in for you are shockingly intriguing. The Mocap done for the game was surprisingly good, the acting on par. If you are one of those people who love games in which you can just abuse the ai- do it. 

The Bad:
I cannot tell you the amount of times cut scenes just didn't load in, or when starting a new mission with an informant, they just froze- both having me to restart the game. Mirrors are fucking unsettling. Driving in this game is such a nightmare. Bushes are made of concrete, I've lost objectives because my car hit an invisible wall, or even an umbrella causing me to spiral out of control. Missions seem to repetitive, much too repetitive for a game that took me almost 70 hours.

My take:
With this game and it's faults one of the things I found myself doing while on missions is just seeing how much chaos I can really cause the game. Pedestrians will just jump out in front of you as if they have a death wish- thus getting hit with a 60's muscle car going 130 mph. By the time someone has called the police you're halfway across the map. The notoriety mechanic in this game is laughable at best. I used my perks a total of 4 times during my play through (to lose notoriety). You can play this game almost completely by stealth (which is a broken and complete mess of a mechanic) because the AI logic is just a mess..

All in all for a game that came out in 2016, I had higher expectations, however knowing the curve balls the developers went through some of this mess is understandable. My overall suggestion is find a play through of the cut scenes and you'll be much better off. I personally found myself wanting to play GTA rather than chugging through this game. But its done and i don't know if i will come back to it to finish the achievements .

This game is best on the graphic but worst compare to the other series.

review:
Is Mafia III a bad game....well not terrible is it worth the 30 hours to play through the strory? Well not really
my main complaint comes down to repetitive mission structure your going the same thing to the last rackets/bosses as you did with the first.  Locations and enemies, character models are recycled and while the story is decent it cant carry the game and that is mentioning nothing of the bugs and glitches that while better than at launch still can plague the game. Last there are so many great games out there not waste your time on mediocrity

review:
Mafia 3 isn't a bad game, I even had fun with it. Sure the gameplay loop was a little repetitive but the setting was cool, the plot was interesting and the music is fantastic. But you know what's not fun? HAVING 31 HOURS OF PLAY TIME WIPED BECAUSE OF A GAME BREAKING BUG!!!! I mean HOLY F*****G SH!T when you complete the second DLC Stones Unturned, you can't access any junction boxes so hope you enjoy an empty map. 

I really wanted to like this game, I did like it, but Hanger 13 doesn't give a crap even though this bug has been around for 3 years (since launch)

review:
[h1]The Ultimate Patience test - Hardcore mode enabled.[/h1]

I am not a person who would gladly place a negative review on a game, I simply tend to ignore it after I finish it. But sometimes you need to draw a line. So here is mine. Keep in mind that this is my personal experience after I completed everything. If you disagree with this and want to share your opinion, feel free to do so, but be polite!

When you read some reviews on Steam which are listing all the negative aspects of this game you may think they are wrong, but I learned they are not. I gave this game more than a simple chance. 

This review you're about to read is coming from a guy who enjoys every Far Cry's level of repetition, from a guy who enjoyed and completed Assassin's Creed Odyssey and all its possible side-missions. And who doesn't have the problem to invest his time in doing something like that. But I have a line too. In one word, playing this game I realized that I am a pure masochist. And even though I completed this game, I think I failed the patience test because I had to write this negative review.

I didn't have the opportunity to play this game before the Definitive update got released, but all the problems that I've seen and read this game had before, they can occur on this edition as well.

This game is almost like an RNG (random number generator) where it may work for one user and for another it doesn't work properly no matter what. Maybe I'm the unlucky one here. But some aspects can't be attributed to luck. This is my personal experience and I didn't expect it's going to be like this.

[h1]The cons:[/h1]
[b]- Graphics:[/b]
Blurred mess with some kind of smudgy orange tint all over the place. I don't understand the decision in making something like this and thinking it may look good and it may give retro style vibe to the game. It just doesn't. I was using Reshade and that was the only possible way to override the mentioned color settings. Maybe it would be better if I didn't play on 27'' monitor with FHD resolution. But I tried with DSR to 1440p and it also looks the same. Blurred mess without Reshade.

[b]- Bugged missions:[/b]
You come to the point where you need to finish a certain mission, press the key to start the sequence and that should be it. Unfortunately, it is. Nothing is happening so you have to restart your game and hope it'll work next time. It usually does work. But that's still broken.

[b]- Glitched achievements[/b]
Now we're talking. If you are an achievement hunter, you, by default, need to play this game 2 times. If everything works fine, that is. Didn't work for me.
In the middle of my first playthrough I found a working solution on how to make your achievements work if the achievements with "counters" are glitched. Those are where you need to kill more enemies in a certain way. Unfortunately, that solution didn't work for every achievement. If you encounter the glitch on your current and probably your main save for the story missions, forget that save. You'll have to start all over again in order to unlock that achievement. Thankfully, you can find some save files on the web and use that if you didn't create your own backups. But that still takes you only after the first part of the story.

[b]- Awful animations:[/b]
Cutscenes are fine and somewhere interesting, depending on your preferences. But in-game dialogues are terrible. You stand in front of a mission-giver like a robot while he is talking something. Once he is done, short and awkward pause comes in and then you give a response. Completely unmotivated or anything that would give some signs of life.

[b]- Raining simulator:[/b]
This game actually looks good when it's raining cause it adds puddles on the roads and that creates nice reflections. But why "simulator"? Because it can rain even if there are no clouds. NPCs are reacting to the rain, you can see they try to get a shelter, walking faster and such. But not in this case scenario. And it rains all the time. A solution I have found on the internet was to die on purpose. Actually works. Although, you get tired of it cause almost every night or morning it starts to rain.
You can maybe find that some people say how this game is set in Gulf Coast of United States (fictional town New Bordeaux) and how it rains there all the time or very often so it's more close to realism. I don't know, didn't check on that. But heads up, you can see through walls in this game, yet again, they decided that the rain should be close to realism? Hard to think so.

[b]- Utterly boring:[/b]
Yes! You remember how  I said I like Far Cry's repetitions? This one is another story. You go to one mission-giver, he talks about something, you go to that location, kill everything that moves, go back and repeat the process because now some other enemies are magically there on the same spots. Really! Really nothing else you need to do in this game. If you consider that the map is not that big actually, you'll find yourself in a box and you can't go out from there. I couldn't stand the fact that you need to do the exact same thing over and over again. Some other games that I mentioned at least have some variety in locations if nothing else.

[b]- Predictive storyline:[/b]
Nothing that would amaze me here. Really nothing. Did you play Mafia 2? Do you remember the ending? Oh, that was something. Here? Nothing. You already know what will happen if you want to see the real ending. And if you are not a sadist in some way you won't miss it. The only thing that was interesting to me is on how you'll divide districts in the city and that some choices have different impact.
On the other hand DLCs were kinda different, so I can say that I enjoyed playing them.

[b]- Stupid AI:[/b]
Every game needs easier mechanics so that the player can beat the game with the stealth. I understand that. But in this game that's on another level. You just need to stand in one place and use the whistle button. Literally. They will come to you so you can take them one by one with stealth approach. Tedious process so if you don't want to be annoyed that much, just don't play that way. On harder level you have some challenge, but that's it.

[h1]The pros:[/h1]
[b]- Performances were fine.[/b]
Stable 60 FPS at 1080p with all settings on max. I have i5 8500, 1660 Ti, 16 GB with Windows 10.

[b]- Uninstalls well.[/b]
Simple enough.


If you had just the main game without DLCs, good for you, you received DLCs for free in the latest Definitive update. If not, don't buy this game for this price. It's a shame and demeaning towards developers to say something like this, but don't pay more than 5 -7 ‚Ç¨ for this game. For most problems in this game there is a fix on the internet. But that still doesn't mean that you need to be a google-expert in order to play this game and finally finish it.

[i][b]Overall rating 2/10[/b][/i]

I told you, I am a pure masochist.
raw_json:

[b]- Utterly boring:[/b]
Yes! You remember how  I said I like Far Cry's repetitions? This one is another story. You go to one mission-giver, he talks about something, you go to that location, kill everything that moves, go back and repeat the process because now some other enemies are magically there on the same spots. Really! Really nothing else you need to do in this game. If you consider that the map is not that big actually, you'll find yourself in a box and you can't go out from there. I couldn't stand the fact that you need to do the exact same thing over and over again. Some other games that I mentioned at least have some variety in locations if nothing else.

[b]- Predictive storyline:[/b]
Nothing that would amaze me here. Really nothing. Did you play Mafia 2? Do you remember the ending? Oh, that was something. Here? Nothing. You already know what will happen if you want to see the real ending. And if you are not a sadist in some way you won't miss it. The only thing that was interesting to me is on how you'll divide districts in the city and that some choices have different impact.
On the other hand DLCs were kinda different, so I can say that I enjoyed playing them.

[b]- Stupid AI:[/b]
Every game needs easier mechanics so that the player can beat the game with the stealth. I understand that. But in this game that's on another level. You just need to stand in one place and use the whistle button. Literally. They will come to you so you can take them one by one with stealth approach. Tedious process so if you don't want to be annoyed that much, just don't play that way. On harder level you have some challenge, but that's it.

[h1]The pros:[/h1]
[b]- Performances were fine.[/b]
Stable 60 FPS at 1080p with all settings on max. I have i5 8500, 1660 Ti, 16 GB with Windows 10.

[b]- Uninstalls well.[/b]
Simple enough.


If you had just the main game without DLCs, good for you, you received DLCs for free in the latest Definitive update. If not, don't buy this game for this price. It's a shame and demeaning towards developers to say something like this, but don't pay more than 5 -7 ‚Ç¨ for this game. For most problems in this game there is a fix on the internet. But that still doesn't mean that you need to be a google-expert in order to play this game and finally finish it.

[i][b]Overall rating 2/10[/b][/i]

I told you, I am a pure masochist.", "timestamp_created": 1592230524, "timestamp_updated": 1592261208, "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 215, "votes_funny": 22, "weighted_vote_score": "0.83955150842666626", "comment_count": 29, "steam_purchase": false, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review: DO NOT BUY. I loved mafia 1 and 2 however this is a buggy mess. I was able to play mafia 3 classic however it was extremely grindy and repeative. The set piece moments were good and the story great. But now they have forced an editon on all players that is even buggier then mafia 3 classic at launch. Another failing was the saving system. Only allowed one save which would be fine however you cannot delete your current save as a bug. Meaning you can never reply it. The trophies/achievments are also grindy as hell and bug stops you from getting them. It has been like this for 4 years. Do not support this bullshit. To get it to work I had to pirate the game after already buying it. The pirated version is free and works better with less bugs.... sad.

review:
This is my second go-around with Lincoln Clay and the collection of criminals, racists and hicks of New Bordeaux. The city, based on a 1968 variation of New Orleans is broken up into turfs controlled by associates of crime boss Sal Marcano. Vietnam vet Lincoln works with a CIA operative to bust up Marcano's hold on the city. For Lincoln, it is all about revenge.

Let me get the one major con out of the way....

It's grindy -- if you read the whole review you'll see why I tolerate the grindiness of the game but it is not for those who hate grindiness. Most of the missions are rinse and repeat. You go after an underboss, you diminish two of the rackets his district controls, and then you kill the underboss. Breaking up the rackets is almost always through infiltrating a building and killing everyone there. It's OK, but mindless and grindy.

The reason I tolerated the grind was because I love the story, and the look and feel of the city. If you love open worlds, this game is worth it. New Bordeaux and the surrounding swamp land is very well designed and detailed. You do feel as if you are in the U.S. south in the 60's. The DLC that comes bundled with the Definitive Edition is worth it too. 

The story is great and the voiceover actors are above average. It is well written but there is a lot of harsh language. Remember, this is largely a story about race and so you should expect a lot of language related to race. 

Finally, the game does allow you to make key decisions that may affect what happens. You work with several people who want a larger piece of the pie. You need to make decisions on what territories they get. Piss one off too many times and you may find yourself with new enemies. 

All-in-all, I would recommend this to those who like open world games, and following a well written storyline adventure.

review: Mafia 3 is a hell of a games, the graphics are great, it's joy for the eyes. The gameplay is interesting but in a way, it's also poor, when you want to advance in the story, you need to follow the same pattern (kill the underbosses, take there business and so on). I feel like they can do a lot better for the enemies IA, and maybe diversify the mission (small missions to obtain a new territory), to gain the feeling of doing something new in the gameplay but also discover something new each time you advance in the story. As for the map, it's pretty and you can feel the atmosphere of New Bordeaux. The gun fight aspect in the game is not that great, i feel like they need to put more action to it, and the animations are repetitive. Final point, one disappointing thing about mafia 3 is the poor development of the sequel story of mafia 2, i mean when i finished mafia 2, i was waiting for a sequel of Vito's adventure and Joe's story but the game failed in the narration by bringing Vito in the story, they didn't need to incorporate them to make the game better (even if it's always cool to see Vito's old face in the game). But i still had a great time playing the game, the feeling of accomplishment when you take a new district, earn more money and more upgrades... Overall mafia 3 is a good game.

review:
This game is way too bloated for it's own good. I bet i could have halved my playtime if I didn't have to kill enforcers, destroy materials, and chase informants for MORE things to destroy at least a dozen times. Honestly it's such a blur. The side missions range from an boringly average to INSANELY     S     L     O    W    . I wish I could have had more of the main game content instead of busy work, because those are the best parts of this game; however, most people are probably not like me and will be stubborn enough to tough it out to the end, and I completely understand. The DLC content can be pretty fun, and an actually good break from the boring shit, but the endgame DLC content for 2 of the campaigns become just MORE time sinks. The bounty hunter missions are pretty fun, but are only 3 long and are really quick to finish, mostly because you're timed to get there in the first place. Along with this, there are wayyyyy too many "collectibles", 90% are not interesting at all, and the magazines you can collect aren't much except just cool looking. It doesn't make sense why the developers would make a singleplayer game such a boring time sink, it's not like I can justify the grind like one could for any MULTIPLAYER video game. Why did I stick through this to the end? For a CRUMB of unique main game content? The best parts of the GAME? VIDEO GAMES ARE SUPPOSED TO BE FUN THROUGHOUT?

Just play Mafia 2 if you're interested in the franchise. Otherwise, don't bother if you want to spend your time with other things. I know i should have.

review:
Mafia III certainly doesn't deserve a lot of the hate it gets; it is essentially a game that ALMOST gets everything right, much like Mafia II did before.

An excellent story that places a twist on your generic revenge narrative, and an eclectic cast of interesting characters is what elevates Mafia III above most third-person shooters I've played before. The story is told in a documentary-like style, having characters from Lincoln Clay's past relay information and anecdotes that you play in a series of flashbacks. This is one way in which the story remains fresh compared to employing other simple plot devices. The setting and the race politics just make the story feel so much more legitimate and alive.

As for the gameplay, Mafia III has the best driving I've seen in any open world video game, fun shooting mechanics, brilliant level design, and an overabundance of content to make your purchase worthwhile. I've gotten 50 hours out of the game including the DLC and the majority of the side missions.

That said, there's too much padded side content to increase Mafia III's longevity, something I've been seeing in games like Assassin's Creed Odyssey, Borderlands 2, and Grand Theft Auto V for years now. The side content in the game is utterly repetitive, just like it is in the games I just mentioned. Why not have fewer but better quests/missions? This gaming trend of quantity over quality admittedly gets old QUICK, and it's no different here.

Another major issue is the insane amount of annoyances in this game: bugs, CTDs, and save corruption. This kind of thing only happens in "unfinished games" that are rushed into distribution before they're ready so that these issues can be "fixed" with patches. Again, the Assassin's Creed, Grand Theft Auto, and Battlefield series come to mind. The problem is, these games are never actually fixed because the next game is rushed into development. Mafia III shouldn't have these issues, but it does.

And don't get me started on the incessant cops. They're not quite Grand Theft Auto V ridiculous, but they're still f#<king ridiculous, taking away some of the fun of the game. I mean, in what universe will cops shoot with the intent to kill and chase me relentlessly for a minor car crash into them, yet look the other way when I fire an RPG into a crowded restaurant? This s#it kills immersion.

Ultimately, Mafia III is a great game just like its predecessor that captures the feel of a modern organized crime ring. That said, it suffers from the same issues that plague major game distributors nowadays - a focus on maximum revenue instead of the consumer.

review: Yeah, no. The first 2 Mafia games were popular for its storytelling. Admittedly, the open world in the first 2 games were a gimmick since there was next to nothing to do in the open world. The open world took a backseat to the games' story. Mafia 3 seems to do the opposite, probably because it wasn't even made by the same developers. There's stuff to do in the open world now but it's filled with Ubisoft levels of repetitive busy work. The story took a major hit in this game. Despite this game being called Mafia 3, this game has very little to do with the mafia. The only mafia connections are reduced to member berries. The only positive I can give to the story is that it never shies away from the sensitive topic of racism during that time period. The other positive thing I could add is that it pushed me to actually play Mafia 1 for the first time. Hopefully I can beat that game before the Definitive remake is released.

review:
When I've played with Mafia for the first time. I did not like it that much. The first game I've played with was Mafia 2.
After some time I've played with the game again and I liked it. After the 3rd game came out I've watched some gameplays and I kinda liked it. One time it was on sale and I bought it.
I've got through the main story in nearly 20 hours and all of those hours were full of action and fun.
The game's story is really interesting and good. It is a bit far from the other 2 games, but apart from that the game is good and replayable.

review: An awesome open world game with a trove of stuff for you to do. The story and cutscenes are super well done, and it's got fantastic polish (although after about 30 hours the bugs start to appear more frequently). I got a good 60 hours out of the game, not including the collectibles. The missions definitely feel a bit more "samey" than a GTA game, but it's still very high quality and an enjoyable experience. It's very rare a game is still constantly introducing new mechanics 40 hours in. Hell, the game doesn't even really feel "started" until about 15 or so hours in.

review:
Mafia 3 more than lives up to the epicness of Mafia 2. This is a very story-driven campaign. You start with nothing and slowly take over territories in order to get revenge on a mob boss in very typical Mafia fashion. Each territory has a unique story but follows the same kind of set up - You meet the main character of the area, You help him/her take it over and move onto the next. It may seem a bit dull but it's not. Each territory has its own unique story and that is the beauty of the game. The developer keeps the high-quality story going from start to finish.

The gameplay is simple yet fun, Similar to previous instalments. I feel the numerous collectables are very needless and don't other anything other than wasted time. The environments are unique and fitting to the time period (the late 60's). The driving controls could have been a bit more satisfying, It's nowhere near as enjoyable as it was in Mafia 2. I love radio options in this game too, Mafia 3 has such a fitting and enjoyable soundtrack that brings the era to life. Honestly, Go buy this game. It's so much fun. I'm having a blast playing it.

review: This game gets a lot of flak for the state it was in at launch, which is fair enough, but it's actually pretty solid. I played the game on release on Xbox one and remember it being way more of a grind than it is now. I don't know if they changed it in an update or if it was just the DLC breaking things up, but my 31 hours flew by. Stones Unturned is good shooty fun. Faster Baby is good driving fun and adds a weed growing and selling mechanic that is a good source of income and something else to do besides destroying Sal Marcano. I honestly didn't like Sign of the Times that much. It didn't fit in with the gameplay and was a chore to get through. Thankfully it was only like an hour and a half tops, and fixing up Sammy's was cool. The combat in this game is AMAZING! Headshots feel and look awesome, takedowns are brutal as fuck, and the stealth... well the stealth is functional. I used a silenced pistol the entire game, so it was rather trivial for me, but the headshots were so satisfying. The story is pretty great as well. There a a few obvious things that Lincoln overlooked, but it sits just (and I mean just) below Mafia 2's story. Lincoln is an alright main character. I think he would have been even better if the story wasn't so spread out.

review:
[b]  If you're someone that really likes historical and action games I would definitely recommend Mafia 3 for you. [/b] The action and gameplay are ok and it‚Äôs a very immersive game, Mafia 3 really makes you feel like you‚Äôre in the 60s or something. [i] But keep in mind that the game has some massive problems that maybe would make you very upset: [/i] 
1 - It has a lot of bugs and glitches that since nowadays weren‚Äôt corrected, some of then are very disappointing, like when you walk through the role map to play a mission and it‚Äôs simply not able to start it, you have to end another one before (SO WTF IT WAS AVAILABLE ON THE MAP?!?!?!).
2 - Some of the missions are very repetitive, making the experience frustrating. Find some cars, invade this place, kill some random dude, pursue some random dude or a mix of those things are pretty much what all the missions in Mafia 3 are.
3 - Side missions don‚Äôt have cutscenes, and I should say that it‚Äôs pretty annoying to see the characters standing there, like a ps2 scene. Btw that‚Äôs something that‚Äôs pretty notable in Mafia 3, although the game was released on 2016, for ps4, when it comes up to cutscenes, I often feel like I‚Äôm playing a ps3 game, it sucks.

In general, what I‚Äôm trying to say is that if you like the action and the historical background (music, guns, cars, architecture and so on) more than you pay attention to the problems I‚Äôve listed, it‚Äôs safe to say that you‚Äôre going to enjoy the game.

review:
I never review anything on steam but Mafia III is something special. I went into it thinking it would be absolute garbage since it's known as the bad one in the series but after playing it I was pleasantly surprised and thought I should throw in my two cents for what it's worth.

I can understand people rate this game as negative just for the sheer amount of bugs throughout. I experienced most if not all of them. Car's spawning halfway in the ground, spawning under the map, spawning in the sky box to come crashing down taking no fall damage, Sound disappearing from my weapons, the game freezing for 10 solid seconds then continuing just fine, It's buggy enough to make you wonder just how this game even came out in the first place. But even with all that said I still kept coming back and played this game all the way to the end and all the DLC added for free just because It is just a blast to actually play when it works. A lot of people say the game is repetitive which i can understand but I never got sick of anything. I don't think it's fair to bash on this game just because "all you do is drive around and shoot things." I mean yeah isn't that all you do is most all other open world games? The repetitiveness doesn't bother me if what I am doing is fun and killing racist asshole mobsters and taking over their districts was a lot of fun.

The story isn't anything new. A pretty simple revenge plot. I did like this story the least out of the Mafia trilogy but it wasn't bad. All the characters were well voice acted and they were believable. The setting of new bordeaux was fantastic and I Loved driving through all the different parts from downtown to the bayou. Mafia 3 also has fantastic songs to listen to on the 3 different radio stations. The guns felt and sounded amazing and honestly if anything there's too many options to take out your enemies. With 7 different "grenades" and 4 different weapon classes all with about 4-10 guns in each I still have guns to try by the end of the campaign.

I'd say this game is worth the money and worth you time. Maybe even a second playthough.

review:
I want to recommend this game, I really do, but there are just so many issues with it.

You need to do a lot of messing with Nvidia control panel to get it to run consistently, and then the game just fucking stops working sometimes. Idk how it runs on AMD cards, but hopefully its not as bad. 

The game is also just paced like hell. Part of it is the restricting nature of the Mafia franchise. The other part is just unlocking shit. Almost every single thing is locked behind 10ish hours of gameplay, and you can only start to unlock things at that point in time. Unlocking improvements is a fucking chore. You need to do so much work to just get your pistols to be more accurate. Your capos need to be rolling in dough before they give you the most basic of help. Cars are also a giant pain to get. I love the customization options.

At 30 hours in, its a giant pain in the ass.

There are also just some quality of life things that are a giant pain in the ass to deal with. There are no cabs in this game. No fast travel. Going to pick up your kickback money shouldn't feel like a chore. Half of the tasks you'll end up doing for your rackets and your leftianants  are slogs because its just you running back and forth across the whole damn map with very little combat to break it up.

The whole game feels like it was left half baked. I'm guessing producers are a culprit here. A lot of the basic issues could have been easily solved with several more months of polish. Not necessarily the padding.

I really wish this game had gotten the money and expertise that GTAV received. The setting and that kind of expertise and attention to detail could have made a game that really would have been great.
raw_json:
{"recommendationid": "70494122", "author": {"steamid": "76561197984157357", "num_games_owned": 0, "num_reviews": 68, "playtime_forever": 2660, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 1670, "last_played": 1591979069}, "language": "english", "review": "I want to recommend this game, I really do, but there are just so many issues with it.

You need to do a lot of messing with Nvidia control panel to get it to run consistently, and then the game just fucking stops working sometimes. Idk how it runs on AMD cards, but hopefully its not as bad. 

The game is also just paced like hell. Part of it is the restricting nature of the Mafia franchise. The other part is just unlocking shit. Almost every single thing is locked behind 10ish hours of gameplay, and you can only start to unlock things at that point in time. Unlocking improvements is a fucking chore. You need to do so much work to just get your pistols to be more accurate. Your capos need to be rolling in dough before they give you the most basic of help. Cars are also a giant pain to get. I love the customization options.

At 30 hours in, its a giant pain in the ass.

There are also just some quality of life things that are a giant pain in the ass to deal with. There are no cabs in this game. No fast travel. Going to pick up your kickback money shouldn't feel like a chore. Half of the tasks you'll end up doing for your rackets and your leftianants  are slogs because its just you running back and forth across the whole damn map with very little combat to break it up.

The whole game feels like it was left half baked. I'm guessing producers are a culprit here. A lot of the basic issues could have been easily solved with several more months of polish. Not necessarily the padding.

I really wish this game had gotten the money and expertise that GTAV received. The setting and that kind of expertise and attention to detail could have made a game that really would have been great.

review: A game that had so much potential only to get it ruined by repetetive quests , shallow world, NPCs that jump under your car for absolutely no reason. The story liine is amazing , the cutscenes are good but at the end it is all ruined by this bland gameplay loop. The game recently recieved a patch that is supposed to fix bugs but for some reason i see no difference. All i see is that my framerate is up in the 80+ fps and yet the game feels like its stuttering and like its running at 30fps lock for some unknown reason . Such a shame. I am afraid that the Mafia Remaster is gonna end up completely in the same way so i dont get my hopes up and neither should you .

review:
Graphics are a strange, inconsistent blend of current gen & 2010. Frame times are very inconsistent with in game settings making little difference (15fps on average between low & high). There are too many issues with the game to get absorbed by the 60's aesthetic & soundtrack. 

Loved Mafia II, can't enjoy this in its current state.

Played on i7 7700 & GTX 1650 Super.
Definitive Edition changes barely anything on the original game, which is a repetitive grind. This game could've been condensed to a 16 hour experience and it would've been better for it.

review: Played the game quite a while before the "definitive" edition, and it was ok. Very hardware hungry, but even with an average pc i found settings that worked for me. The gameplay is not as good as in the previous titles, but i still had some fun driving the cars around. Now with the release of the "definitive" edition, the game is unplayable for me. Even with the lowest settings i cannot get a stable framerate without contant stuttering. My pc is not the best (1060, 16gb ddr4, 6600k), but its also not old enough to justify this mess. Especially if it worked before. Now i spent a few days trying to optimise, changing settings inside the driver, game or both with no improvement. Since they replace the working version with the "definitive" edition in the steam library, i can DEFINITELY not give it a thumbs up.

review:
This review is dedicated to Take-Two interactive. Your predatory publishing practices are, and ought to be unacceptable for your utter disregard for not only the developers of our favorite games, but to those who consume the games developers like Star Theory create. The love we have for these games will now reflect on your games. My opinions toward the quality of your games don't matter, and neither do your opinions about us, the players. You have singlehandedly destroyed our expectations for your future games, and killed one of the best independent games of our generation, Kerbal Space Program.

Shame. On. You.

review:
The cutscenes and cinematics are great, I highly recommend watching it on youtube as a sort of story/film.
However the gameplay is literally as follows;
Go to a point, watch cutscene (boils down to, "the bad guy wont leave until you annoy them")
Go to another point, talk to information (Kill these things to annoy big boy)
Go to point, kill
Repeat...
it's not fun, it feels lackluster and dull.

review:
I usually don't write comments to games, but I felt obligated to correct the injustice this game gets and prevented me from playing this game for so long. 
I guess at the time of the launch there were many issues that caused people to get upset, but I can tell you the game runs 100% with minor glitches.
Although there is truth about the repetitively felling of the missions, the gameplay is very fun, you can approach missions stealth or guns blazing,  and the I find the driving very enjoyable.
The story is really good, voice overs are top of the line, but the best part are the DLC, they are really different from the main story gameplay, very interesting, and executed flawlessly.
Also the main story about the african-american community feels more relevant then ever, I don't think many games were able to address this issue so well.

review:
[i]Light and Darkness[/i]

Ratings are a fickle thing, and Steam ratings are easily skewed towards one side or the other. This game has problems on various levels, however I don't think that on a scale as simple as "positive" or "negative" I could ever rate it negatively.

First off: Yeah, the bugs. There's lots of them. Gamebreaking even. And a bunch of them seem to have been imported into the Definitive Edition, which is annoying but ironically also helpful  because you can draw from old solutions. Outright crashes, game not responding to inputs, mission NPCs not responding or missions not appearing on the map, game freezes, sound partially disappearing when tabbing out... and that's just what I can recall off the top of my head. Thankfully restarting fixes all of these. However, we can all agree they shouldn't be in what is supposedly the "definitive" release.

With that out of the way: The story. If Mafia I & II were Martin Scorsese, Mafia III is Quentin Tarantino. Out with ye olde wiseguys, in with Lincoln Clay, a Vietnam war veteran and member of the Black Mob. After being betrayed and the murder of his closest associates, he's out for revenge by taking over the city piece by piece and weakening his ultimate foe in the process.

What starts as a cool concept (albeit not novel) becomes tedious and grindy rather quickly. There's 9 sectors of the city you must gradually take over to progress in the story. And it's more or less always the same. I mean, it's kinda satisfying to see your criminal enterprise grow but then again the gameplay isn't intricate enough to feel like a simulation.

One of the game's strongest points is probably the portrayal of the times: Racial segregation in the 60s & 70s USA. The Vietnam war. The grim reality of racism and discrimination against POCs everyday, any place. There's a particular mission in Frisco Fields that gave me the creeps and I made damn sure to kill everybody in a certain room (no spoilers).

Playing this game these days feels, coincidentally, very relevant again. The death of George Floyd in an act of police brutality, the ensuing riots and protests. We've made strides in overcoming racism but it's sadly not a thing of the past, yet.

[b]7/10[/b]

review:
First and foremost, this game is a massive letdown compared to Mafia II, a lot of features that made the game so unique and brilliant have been removed or edited for the worst and I'll explain how below.

[h1]Combat[/h1]

The shooting mechanics of the game have changed very little compared to Mafia II, it still follows a fairly generic third-person shooter style of combat, while not bad by any stretch, I wouldn't say that it's breaking any records. One aspect of the game I personally prefer over Mafia II is that you seem to have less ammo in comparison to the previous games in the Mafia series which means you have to be a bit more conservative with your ammo before you get the upgrades. On top of that you now have the ability to blind fire with extreme inaccuracy. If you're looking into Mafia III primarily as a shooter game, I don't know if this would win you over by its self. Melee combat has been severely cut down with a lack of true counters and combos, you have one melee button and one dodge button.

[h1]Driving[/h1]

The driving mechanics of Mafia III took a huge step down from Mafia II, the cars no longer feel heavy and realistic to drive, they've swapped over to a much more user friendly/arcade style of driving, even if you choose to swap over to simulation style driving. Cars are still impacted by the various types of weather which makes for an exciting experience as you have to ease on the throttle and brake early when it's raining, or you can drive a car like it's stolen (which it probably is!) during summer. You are no longer able to store cars in your garage or customise every vehicle like you were able to do in Mafia II, instead you can make cosmetic modifications to your vehicle at Big Rick's Custom Auto, the cosmetic modifications provide more customisable parts than in previous mafia games, but with less options per part such as fewer paint colours. Overall, the driving in Mafia III isn't terrible, but definitely a disappointment considering how good Mafia II was.

[h1]Story/Gameplay[/h1]

The story of Mafia III is significantly less linear than Mafia II, it allows you to take over various districts and distribute them to your fellow underbosses, Cassandra, Thomas Burke, and Vito Scaletta. It's not the first of its kind to do this, but I think it's been fairly well implemented in this allowing you to take over regions by doing various tasks within the area with varying levels of risk and reward. Once you have taken over a district you have to make the decision of who to give it to, with different results depending on who you give them too. 

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

Mafia III is far from the best game I've ever played, it definitely has its flaws and lacks the same depth as its predecessor, but I can't say I didn't enjoy going around the city, taking down the criminal empire and taking control of the city. The story is also a great continuation from the second game in the trilogy. Overall I simply can't recommend this game as a follow up to one of the greatest mafia/mob games of all time.

The shooting mechanics of the game have changed very little compared to Mafia II, it still follows a fairly generic third-person shooter style of combat, while not bad by any stretch, I wouldn't say that it's breaking any records. One aspect of the game I personally prefer over Mafia II is that you seem to have less ammo in comparison to the previous games in the Mafia series which means you have to be a bit more conservative with your ammo before you get the upgrades. On top of that you now have the ability to blind fire with extreme inaccuracy. If you're looking into Mafia III primarily as a shooter game, I don't know if this would win you over by its self. Melee combat has been severely cut down with a lack of true counters and combos, you have one melee button and one dodge button.

review:
A broken technical mess that the Definitive Edition fails to address. 

An Xbox One controller over Bluetooth ONLY works if you're using Steam Big Picture with the Steam Overlay enabled. However, the game has a widely known bug that makes the right thumb stick highly sensitive to the point of being unplayable if you have the Steam Overlay enabled regardless of the sensitivity settings in-game. The controller will also stop working if the game is minimized or if another application takes focus. 

Some settings don't appear in the launcher or the game flat out doesn't honor some of the settings. Some of the settings if set in-game require the game to be restarted. The full screen setting keeps getting reset to windowed on next launch if I alt-tab out of the game. The UI scaling options are seemingly broken as I made the settings well within the visible screen space of my monitor, yet the UI was still going off the edges of the screen.

What little I could play of the first mission the audio was broken with missing gun shot sounds.

The game HAS to be launched from Steam - otherwise it will just silently crash and make a blank dump file in the game's directory.

review:
I fucking love driving around in this game.

There are lots of things to like about this game and lots of things to dislike. The city is amazing and driving around in it is an experience like no other. The story and production are great and aside from some spotty voice acting from a few minor characters it is on point. 

The gameplay itself gets repetitive and securing all the rackets is a drag. But once that's done and you can focus on the story it's all good. The inclusion of  the DLC helps a lot, as this breaks things up and adds some much needed variation to the core gameplay. 

On the whole, if you can get through the boring bits this game is a lot of fun with a powerful story. A light ReShade to tighten up the graphics goes a long way also.

review:
Pros/Cons-
although I can recommend Mafia 3 to anyone there are a ton of bugs that cause progression blocking[Con] and achievements from being completed. All can be immediately fixed by relaunching the game. [Con] Poorly optimised even though I have a core i3 8100 the game has been noted to run poorly at higher frame-rates. However, there is a design element where some lighting [Pros] glosses over leather, walls of buildings and other textures in the world which are real pleasant to look at and feel like they reflect the time period. 
[Con] Can be a slog to get through, some unskippable dialogue but I have completed the game 4-5 times, as well as all dlc.[Pros] which were fantastic especially the cult dlc.
Music is incredible [Pros] to enjoy some moments in the sunset with tunes from Sam Cooke, Creedence, Stones. And action is overall varied and fun [Pros] with items/weapons and possibilities to create cool scenarios and killing mobs of enemy A.I - which if they were a little worse and not as aggressive would have been really stupid and a joke which they are not really, most of the time. 
[Pros] Multiple endings - one secret ending.
[Pros] Animation - possibly the best part for me when I came back after a year or two to play this game again was how much depth of character animations and the variety you can see throughout the world and your play-through.
[Pros] Cut scenes are real nice to look at and story was A- okay!

The old Mafia III was one of my faves until the download of Definitive Edition. Now the game is almost completely unplayable. It's so slow and it doesn't matter how much I turn the resolution settings down, it's still running like molassas. I've tried to re-install the original game from disc but it seems to default to Definitive Edition. This thing really needs a patch badly for PC. It also keeps giving me this error message saying that my computer specs aren't up to parr which is total BS because I'm on an Alienware laptop with i7 2.8ghzs, Nvidia 1060 chip, and 24 gig of Ram. There is nothing wrong with the specs of my PC, rather there is something wrong with the specs of Definitive Edition. What we all want is a couple of more DLC's not some sorry reboot of what was once a great game.
